hobby.message: Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?
Political literature still your guilty pleasure?
I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Yes. Scanners by the lifts, too. Routine, they say.
Nothing changes much down here.
I keep to my corner, work on typewriters.
Recent mess made it harder to get supplies, that's all.
Still scanning. Entry takes longer now.
I don't linger upstairs—safer to keep routines simple.
I restore old typewriters at home. Prefer analog.
Paper's harder to find since tribunal week.
Crowds make even finding ribbons a chore.
Yes. Full scans every time you cross the threshold now.
Makes errands too eventful for my taste.
I restore and collect antique typewriters. Good way to pass quiet hours.
Typing eases my nerves when city feels off.
Last week, access error locked me out with a half-serviced Underwood.
Had to finish repair by candlelight after midnight.
They are, and it's unpredictable. Sometimes double scans, sometimes nothing.
Reminds me why I keep hobbies low-tech—antique typewriters never ask your score.
Spent half yesterday restoring an Olympia, power blinked twice from council grid rerouting.
Lost a whole page of writing in the dark. Reminded me to keep spares.
Even paper's inspected lately. Had a neighbor borrow some after his audit.
Sometimes, sharing a machine feels like a pact. You pass trust with the ribbon.
The system can scan faces, not motives.
Still scanning, yes. Patterns are random now—some days I pass, next I'm flagged.
Hard to work on my old Remingtons when power and entry change by the hour.
After the tribunal, I began typing journals for the 'restored'—people who vanished, lost their words.
Restoring typewriters changed. Now it's not just parts, it's memory on a page.
Last Thursday, I wrote alongside a 'ghost' neighbor. He hadn't touched a typewriter in years.
We traded stories through keystrokes as sirens blared outside.
I sometimes feel the old machines are safer than the network ever was.
In times like this, ink and ribbon make more sense than algorithms.
hobby_answer: Yes, still tuning.
Old machines last longer than new ones.
It keeps me occupied when the networks go out.
Access checks lately have made it harder to fetch supplies.
After the tribunal, even my workspace feels exposed.
I still keep the old typewriters running.
Nothing digital, if I can help it.
Strange—paper’s become more valuable since last week’s leaks.
Hard to get ribbons when the system stutters, though.
Building security checks slow things down.
The tribunal’s made everyone nervous, myself included.
Still tuning antique typewriters, yes. Best way to keep sharp.
You'd be surprised how mechanical things outlast every algorithm update.
Since the leaks, I’ve had trouble accessing my usual markets for spare parts.
Nearly lost a wheel last weekend—had to improvise with scraps.
Odd feeling, writing while the city watches broadcasts about restoration and erasure.
I keep backup supplies hidden; some habits die hard.
The recent audit requests forced me to move my journals out of sight.
I always return to the typewriters—Empire, Adler even one old Torpedo.
Machines never ask for credentials or log your keystrokes.
The leaks and public trials turned every collector paranoid—now even ribbons feel contraband.
Last week, a ghost citizen borrowed my machine for a few hours—strange experience.
He hadn’t written in years, you could tell from the way he paused.
After the tribunal, paper feels almost illicit. I’m careful about what stays visible.
I stash finished pages in unlikely places, just in case.
Funny, personal history now seems riskier to preserve than public records.
Still restoring them, yes. Empire, Adler, Olympia—each with its quirks I prefer to analog.
Started as habit, became lifeline once the BCI closed in on privacy.
When Halden’s controls slipped and the leaks hit, I noticed prices soar—everyone chasing untraceable tools.
A ‘restored’ neighbor and I spent an afternoon on mine, typing quietly, doors locked.
He’d lost his journals to erasure—needed that tactile weight of a physical page.
The tribunal made me anxious about keeping my own notes. Almost routine, hiding them from random audits now.
Supply runs have changed. I barter for ribbon, sometimes write on backs of BCI printouts.
Strange, documenting your days by hand. Feels like an act the system forgot.
Sometimes I wonder if Halden himself ever kept a journal off-grid, after all.
